titleStmt.title: M109 [The Reader: At what point in Elizabethan drama...]. Typescript, fragment, with the author's ms. corrections, unsigned and undated. 9p.
titleStmt.author: Virginia Woolf

publicationStmt.authority: The Estate of Virginia Woolf, administered by the Society of Authors

msIdentifier.repository: Henry W. and Albert A. Berg Collection of English and American Literature

physDesc.p: M109 [The Reader: But under the ceiling, on the seats, there were gentlemen...]. Typescript, fragment, with the author's ms. corrections, unsigned and undated. 9p.
Numbered 26-27, 31, 34-35. Page 30 filed as p. 178 verso in her Between the Acts, later typescript with ms. fragment.
On fol. 1 verso: [The moment and other essays. Mrs Thrale] typescript
On verso of p. 26-27: [Between the Acts] manuscript fragment

handNote.p: Holograph writing by the documents' main hand, Virginia Woolf

correction.p: Apparent errors have been explicitly corrected in sic / corr tags, wrapped in a choice element.

interpretation.p: Names and references to places and literary works have been wrapped in rs tags which link to annotations and secondary material.

projectDesc.p: Text encoded as part of 'The Digital "Anon": A Digital Genetic Edition of Virginia Woolf's Final Essays'. This project, funded by Leverhulme Grant ECF-2022-602, seeks to construct a TEI-XML based digital edition of the drafts of 'Anon' and 'The Reader', among the final documents Woolf wrote before her death.

div.p:
At what point in E (Elizabethan) drama a is the reader born? at what point does one come to be aware of their [shape?] in the play: of the presence of the audience: of the that of paper drawing up the past; & become in a room reading alone? With of course. He It was
Sh (Shakespeare) who created the reader. And changed liter

It was h (her) marriage however that brought about her peculiar relationship with . Had she been happy, she would never have known him as she did. It was through him that she got what denied -- stimulus, society, an outlet for her irrepressible curiosity and ambition. But the freindship (friendship) between the old man and the young wife went far depper (deeper) than allowed the world to guess. Johnson was not merely a distingusihed (distinguished) guest at the dinner table. He had the run of th (the) house. He knew th (the ) dark passages and the cupboards with their skeletons. Mrs Thrale told him all her troubles. She turned to him when Queeney snubbed her; when Mr Txxxxxx Thrale took another mistress; when ruin threatned (threatened) them; when one after another the children fell ill, and died. "What shall I do? What can I do? has th flattery of my mxmxmxmxmmxmmmxxxmmx freinds (friends) made me too proud of my own

But under the celing (ceiling), on the seats, there were gentlemen, and noblemen, men versed in Latin and Greek; scholars, courtiers, statesmen. Their silence was equally profound. But their influence was also effective. ThxmxBaconsxxmxmx and found what suited them too in the plyhouse (playhouse)

for ever weaving nets and threading mazes mist (must) relax them
slves (themselves). The must have players to divert her. With all his craft and caution he himself emdoies (embodies) substantias (substantiates) his meditations, gives them a body, a name a shape.
"Nay, retire men cannot, when they would: neihter (neither) will they when it were Reason: But are impatient of privateness even in Age and Sicknesse, which require the Sa dow ([Shadow?]): Like old Townemen (Townsmen) that will still be sitting at their strete d or door, those who thereby they offer Agge (Age) to Scorn."
Even the [crowd?] pressure of great tho ts (thoughts) issue in a concrete shape. These short meditations were themslves (themselves) making it possible for the dramatist to [illeg.] impart them where they seemed
i appropitae (inappropriate). For Everything when times are abobrent (absorbent) yields some savour to the stew. The i responsible (irresponsible) mountbanks (mountebanks), clothed in their invisble (invisible) garment of anonymity were Gos spies, in the streets, also at Court. If at or at , one of them caught sight of that grave inscrutbale (inscrutable) figure, he could uickly (quickly) add him to t (the) list of characters. And hyperbole, though the
gr ndl gs (groundlings) lusted fot (for) it, required correction. Bacon
despsing (despising) th (the) thetre (theatre) for its hyperbole was hel (held) contempt for the stage w (was) medicinal. He was teaching them to speak slowly, closely, subtly: to stiffen their poetry with prose: A great age is like youth in th (the) individual. Any hint is heard. Any voice takes effcet (effect). Criticism, a grave an (man) frwoning (frowning) in his corner of the royal box is drawn into affecting the current. And so, as th (the) seasons pass, the aristocratic contempt sevres (severs) to restrain; The cabbbed (crabbed) prose of Bacon is seized and transfomred (transformed). The plays are

p.sup: of what was due to her birth ââ then, as she grows older, she fights, even in the Kings presence, for her land

div.p:
much sharper. As these faculties became atrophied, he became more conscious of the suggestions and associations of words. Txxxs One word written in Elizabathn (Elizabethan) spelling bxmxmxmxmx xxxx has suggestions that give it almost another meaning. It suggests other manners, other clothes; the difference between one society and another. Then as reading becomes a universal habit, readers split off into many varieties. There are the specialised readers, whose power of darwing (drawing) out the meaning of words is tremendously developed; so that they remain attached to certn (certain) aspects of the printed wxxdxx page--the scholars, the students. At the opposite end of the scale, there is the very large class of perfectly literate people whose eyes travel over miles of print yearly, yet never read a word. Some way where between the two, The reader at the present moment exxxxxsx is placed somewhere between these two extremes. And his faculty is a very
curous (curious) one. He has the power to make houses and places, men and women and their thoughts and emotions
isible (visible) to him, from marks on a piece of paper.

Somehwere (Somewhere) between the two comes the reader. His faculty is a very curious one. He has the power to make houses and places visible from marks on a ipiece (piece) of paper; to draw emitons (emotions) of very (every) kind; and also some quality that is independent of emotion; form; unity. He is capable of all the impulses of a writer; but lacks the power of creation. His influnece (influence) upon what is wr tten (written) at any time is immense; In times of public stress, for instance, the writer is uincapable (incapable) of swriting (writing); in part at least because he has no audience. The life of a reader is thus
Thus the life of a reader is bound up in the life of the book. a xxxx constantly merging is to some extent the life of the book.

It was to satisfy this unshaled blind infant,
s retching (stretching) out his hands and covering his eyes in the Eliza bethan playhouse that the oew (owe) the Elizabethans novels. or that very curious book a half born book; a book that is still amorphous
neother (neither) one thing nor the othet (other); a book that cannot walk; and yet now and then like an unwildy (unwieldy) child gambols and breaks the ornmanets (ornaments). But while lived, the novel was always turning into the play. The reader was too weak to make his influence felt.
